body.p: The American Society M. C. I.

By invitation of Rev. Mr. Bokum one of the Vice Presidents and trav-
elling agent of this society, we attended on the even. of the 27th ult. a ?
of a meeting held for the purpose of organizing an auxiliary society in
this city. From his speech based upon the XXXVII of Ezekiel from 1-15
verses (which is strangely enough as our readers know is one of He? of
the Passover) we learned that the society has in view to heal the “dry
bones”, the remnants of the house of Israel, who are scattered “in the valley”
meaning the whole earth, in such a manner that the spirit of the gospel
may reach and animate them. But this favor to our race is not to be
forced upon us as of old by the fire & the sword, nor as in modern
times by abuse & exclusion from public employment, which procee
dings be characterized as anti-christians & barbarous (yest how many
anti-christians and barbarians do exist according to this view, not omitting
the king of Prussia and the queen of England in whose countries the Jews are
not equals with their Christian neighbours); but by acts of kindness,
charity and benevolence; he urged it at the gospel should not be forced upon our notice
by words of the preacher but to teach us its practical effects by itself
kindness ? as should prove to the Jews that its spirit is one of real
goodness & virtue. He stated that with this view the society had through
its agent in N. Y. given away a great deal of money to the poor from
$5 and up to one hundred Dollars to one individual; but that in
? instance had the charity been improperly applied by the recipients.
? last is high praise in favour of the ? of the poor Jews in the
city many of whom are in abject want of even the necessities of life
? the ? of Mr. Finestro. Mr. Bokum farther gave an account

of his progress thus far in human ?, and spoke of a public meeting
with Mr. Lawrence Blumenthal at Chambersburg, who by the
courtesy of Mr. Bokum obtained the permission of making an exposition
of the tenets of Judaism before a crowded church in that town.
(We may probably have to say something more of this address of our
friend in a future number.)—He also advocated to the establish-
ment of a ?prick at Jerusalem in the person of a known
of state under the patronage of the Queen of Britain and the
King of Prussia. He spoke of the alleged infidelity of which we
have lately heard a good deal as existing among our people,
and he ascribed it, as also the same phenomenon among
the catholics, to our acceptance of tradition for us as contained in the Talmud
and for them as embraced in the so called superstitious practices ari-
sing therefrom; and he alludes to the new congregation established
in London in opposition to rabbinical authority, as a legitimate
consequence of the missionary labours of the London Society
for evangelizing the Jews, who he averred had opened by their
publication &c the eyes of our brethren in England to the errors
of their ? to the Talmud.* (*How will our friends of
the new congregation of B? Street relish the allegation
that their reform is the legitimate result of a society
the object of which is the destruction of the Jewish religion?
For our part we should be sorry indeed were any one to ascribe
any act of ours to the result of such unfriendly advice; and we
hope that they will boldly deny the assumptions of the missionary.
We will ?say, that this is not the first time that the opponents
of Judaism have gloried over the secession (and have feigned to

discover therein a gradual approach to Christianity. We
think that, much as we differ from the gentlemen who have
too hastily adopted a new form of worship, that they will be
grieved as much as we were mortified to hear such notices
ascribed to them; and if they feel inclined we offer them our
magazine to reply to these unfounded charges, they may
please to entrust us with a temperate reply exposition calculated
for our paper.]—He stated also that is the object of Mr. ?
to employ missionaries to the Jews in all large
?, and to station one of them in Philadelphia. He referred likewise to our labours, and
stated something about a controversy which we might probably wage
against each other, for the sake of ministerial conviction; and in demanding
public support for the Jewish Chronicle he stated that the managers will
carefully exclude everything calculated to offend; and nothing should
be said which could wound the feelings of an Israelite.

The above is a meager synnopsis of the Rev. gentleman's
remarks, which appeared to be contemporaneous; we were not in a favourable
position to take note, if even we had been inclined to do so, yet we
think that we have reported him fairly and for our purpose fully.
Our readers will see from the above that the weapons are changed,
but that our religion is nevertheless to be attacked. Flattery & money are
to do what violence in the first instance old and coarse rudeness in
more modern times failed to accomplish. We trust that there
is not much danger to be apprehended from such means,
nevertheless there may be a few “whose heart is turning? this
day from the Lord their God;” and it behoves us then to omit
no means in our power to counteract such deeds of our oppo-
nents. Of one thing our Jewish friends may rest assured, that if money
can purchase souls, they will be ready paid for; because we see

that there is a false species of philanthropy spreading
over the land which is anxious to catch every straggler and to
take away any wandering sleep that has missed our fold. As
for us we are concerned we regard an inimical everyone who comes
to deprive us of our religion, be the means or the ? what they may; and though we are personally friendly
to Mr. Bokum, both as a gentleman and a preacher, we certainly
must look upon the efforts he is making as by no means an evidence
of good will towards our belief. We cheerfully accord to him the praise
of moderation and candour; but it would be much better were all
this moderation & candour exerted to allay prejudices instead of
drawing away perhaps some unworthy members from our church.

Respecting the charge of infidelity, we fear that there is some
truth in it; we do not believe that modern Jews are skeptics, but
that a practical infidelity regarding religious duties has obtained
alas! too much currency cannot be denied. We mean not to enter into the discussion
this month; but only to call the attention of our brethren to the fact
that others besides Jews watch their conduct and that their
neglect of religion brings them to honour, and even causes
them to be suspected of unbelief in that blessed faith for which
many would shed their last drop of blood, altho their
conduct bet? so much indifference.

Lastly with regard to our own self we have never promised
to wage a controversy with any man. We probably shall
admit controversial articles if we think proper; but nothing
shall induce us to be always tilting like some anxious knight errant
against all comers. Indeed no one shall provoke us, if we can

keep our temper; and we will use our discretion in this
as in every thing else, and act independently from of all parties.
The Occident was commenced to diffuse knowledge in our
religion; and this we mean to do whilst we continue its editor;
avoid mere controversy which is only a trial of skill—is therefore evidently not fit suited to our
object. We nevertheless assure our friends that we neither fear
nor want religious arguments; all we meant to say, we will not
be provoked for any special object; which would evidently be
the case were we to enter the lists regularly once a month
against the Jewish Chronicle or its reverend editor.

Nonetheless we thank Mr Bokum for his conciliatory
manner, and we hope always to meet him with equal
courtesy both personally and if occasion demands it before
the public. With these remarks we take our leave for
the present from the AS.M.C.I. but likely not longer than
next month.
